EZVIq_fP8DVnUWwm1xVkfA.review_text: Very Good Food, Service and Atmosphere........

ZJMrk2BwAkN0Dtc73qtN8g.review_text: cozy, functional, unpretentious, well-priced, good service.  We went during the north beach fest, and these guys were even keeled about it, when they could have been up-itty and annoyed.  Peroni on draft.  Panini's looked great, i'll be coming back for lunch on a regular basis. Bathroom sucked, whats new, its north beach.

Qd5GyT45vcCydR2mM9dcmg.review_text: Mario's is more than the sum of its parts.  It's one part old wooden bar, European cafe, cozy corner hangout, and piping hot, grilled sandwicheria.  I went there last Saturday to pop in for a late night sandwich while waiting for friends, and settled in comfortably and quickly into one of the corner tables.  There was no bump or bustle, but it was still pleasantly alive.  My sandwich was near perfection, and I was disappointed I had to gobble it down so quick to meet my mates.  I could have easily spent more time lounging at Mario's over a tiramisu and coffee...

4IjzfbO7XKFNWWVufHNhww.review_text: At first when I was told to meet for lunch at the "Cigar Store" I was a little thrown. Upon my groups hungry arrival the staff was really friendly and helped us be the (annoying people with the big group) that needed to gather more chairs.   The Hot Foccacia Sandwiches are amazing and served really piping hot. From what I could gather they cook them right behind the bar on what seems to be a small pannini press. The ingredients were fresh and the group consensus was to come back.   Seating: The table at the front window overlooks the streets and Jackson Park which is fun to watch. Grab it if it is free. There are also tables outside so if it is a nice day opt to sit there and watch the tourists wonder by.

fagcapi3Lzeu9LWUUlJYuA.review_text: Came here with one of my new roommates as this is a favorite spot of his, and I have to say it was pretty good! Nestled in north beach, this Italian spot does a pretty good ceasar salad and we had something else resembling enchiladas stuffed with different fillings. Those were pretty good but I think next time I'm going for something a bit more my speed- sandwich or pasta or something (if they have those). Split a bottle of wine, which was great, and chatted with people at the next table after they overheard our conversation regarding my roommates slut of an ex-girlfriend. I really like the bathroom for some reason, which I think has to do with the slanted ceiling, like you're peeing in an attic. Check this place out, it's got a relaxed, local vibe with good people all around.

SVtNctg9k2QOGj0znfHVwQ.review_text: SUPER hipster, but a damn good sandwich.   My friend and I were feeling some sandwiches so she'd suggested this place. Super glad she did.   It feels much more like a bar than a sandwich spot. And it has a very hipster feel. But I can't deny that they made a ridiculously good meatball sandwich. The meat, the sauce, the bread, the cheese...all of the things!!  So on a nice summer day enjoy the outside seating, or even go across the street and eat in the park. But wherever you eat it, you'll enjoy the sandwich.

6z26YTb8Dz_jlsgjt7qOPQ.review_text: delicious paninis, awesome cappucinos, and oh my god tiramisus...i'm drooling thinking about my wonderful lunch here yesterday.  the service is a little robotic, but as long as my food is good i'm going back!

lConjPFTZqz4zWELK_EJtw.review_text: What we had:    Italian sausage pizza and Caesar salad  We were mislead by the myriads of reviews and high ratings.  We found the food regrettable especially since we had high expectations from Little Italy.  I wanted a do-over at another pizza place, but my daughter refused to participate and I wasn't about to chow down on a slice of pizza alone.    The pizza lacked flavor.  There was only a traceable amount of cheese and a slight sweet hint that we didn't care for.  The Caesar was unremarkable.

t0r4rT-_b-Y4bAoZba8h6Q.review_text: Despite the name, there are no Cigars in use or on sale here. It's just a restaurant. And a damned good one. Try the meatball sandwich, quite delectable. Parking is a problem, but this is San Francisco, so I can't really complain about that too much. Prices are okay, a little high.

GbblKnri6ovFZI-E8j3kIw.review_text: Great bar for a casual bite. The wine is just okay but they make nice aperitifs too.  I recommend the grilled eggplant sandwich on foccacia bread (with balsamic vinaigrette, feta, tomato, arugula).

8dbSdpvNMkz8-MZ8QByrTQ.review_text: Meatball sandwiches, YUMMMM!  Right down the street from my place, EVEN BETTER!    I went through a phase of craving their meatball sandwiches almost on a daily basis.  Apparently, you can't eat meatball sandwiches for every meal (or so they say ...), but I still try to come here at least once a week.  It's my neighborhood favorite, and I make sure to take all my guests from out of town here.    From here, you can see all the craziness at Washington Square park, the parrots, and throngs of tourists staring in the window wondering where the cigars are. You get the best view (and most space) at the corner table.    The bathroom is the size of a kid's shoebox.

rD2tJLlrXnyLnc8X0GPlEg.review_text: Go there Saturday to sit outside, watch people at Washington square park, have a beer, maybe even a great sandwich. Pay next to nothing, yelp about it and come back next week.

m8Ck4pNpWOaXk9yyDXD5hQ.review_text: Try the chicken panini or the chicken focaccia. Delish. Small size coffee, not over priced. We'll be back for sure.

6A4QMfBAbuxUP5ZZWZ8hvw.review_text: This is a fabulous little corner cafe in the heart of north beach. I love sitting outside on a hot day, sipping white wine and snacking on a delicious panini. The people-watching from this corner is great, as it is right across the street from Washington Park, and the food is wonderful. They cook it right inside at the bar in a large wood burning oven. The staff is kind and attentive. This place has a lot of character is a small, quaint, non-pretentious spot that doesn't ever feel touristy. Definitely check it out.

ILz8ApVEgTqbv5LnC6PyuA.review_text: Great Food, great drinks, great service. I need to go here more often...

a3gZmBACfe290XDwTcrtrw.review_text: An epic meatball sandwich. No words to describe the experience. Simply incredible.  Love the vibe, even though last time I was here the service was better, I still don't really care as I did come specifically for this sandwich. Ha.   Beer selection is small but right on the money. Love the park across the street. Makes the places vibe even cooler.   Even love the hipsters that fill up the place. They are from the positive kind ;)

sbWem88kDUO6tDNbKpl-_A.review_text: The sandwiches are unbelievable here!  I am a fan of heated sandwiches, and Mario's has an oven similar to a pizza oven that they use to heat the sandwiches.  The service is always quick and courteous.  The location couldn't be better.  I do enjoy people watching at Mario's, and the beer is out of this world.

rp_cK3PN78kqRt_suzjRwg.review_text: Tucked in a corner in the heart of North Beach, this is purely a San Francisco experience and great for people watching. You can't go wrong with any of the Focaccia and Panini sandwiches at this old Italian North Beach institution. Coffee is good and strong. Hit and miss on getting in as space is very cramped in this wedge shaped venue. Best to go at an off time.

AoBCZN72QIYofUnbQlaAGw.review_text: I will do dirty, dirty things for a Chicken Sandwich #2

M7a-eJMUJGYeMkOlLMniMw.review_text: It's odd that I avoided this place, but that's another langley porter story on my girl interrupted days.  I love all the sandwiches, especially the the sausage, meatball, and eggplant ones. My only complaint is that the focaccia bread could be sliced in half for a filling sandwich.  I love the old time feel of the place.

R2p221627ZK5IhFBVI0OzQ.review_text: It's an easy place to walk past, so don't walk past it anymore and go in.

8Wt4_xi5WOWdEp706ZBuoA.review_text: Mario's is a lovely, unpretentious, and comfortable cafe.  It's small and there are a few tables that overlook that park, some outdoor seating, and a bar that takes up most of the restaurant.  They have beer on tap and that always makes me happy.  My boyfriend and I split a grilled eggplant foccachia sandwich and house salad. Both were delicious.

1-sKWNYf2D-LUcybA9NQPg.review_text: Excellent place, with a lot of character.  Feels like one of these old café-bars from Southern Europe.  Both coffee and desert were excellent.  The place is cozy or crammy, depending on your perspective.  Servers are on the slow side, but extremely polite.

WZpM1tR5nMIj618C4D-RcA.review_text: OK, folks. I get the charm of this cafe's location and setup. Sipping a coffee or glass of wine in the corner or outside at a table on a warm afternoon (today was unusually warm) is a great way to spend time. But I bellied up to the bar for one of the panini's and walked away (far too many minutes later) having eaten half of what must be described as the least flavorful sandwich I've ever spent good money on in this town.   The big, sloppy, hot foccacia sandwiches ordered by others looked more appealing and I understand this might be about my choices, but come on! My "panini" came on a grocery store roll that was filled with mediocre lunch meat, almost no blue cheese (it was a smoked turkey/blue cheese sandwich) and a few red onions. The only  distinguishable flavor was the burnt bottom. I'm OK with dark grilling ... a little scorch can make the sandwich. But it was the ONLY flavor stand-out.  Service was friendly enough and they treated the regulars very well. My server saw the disappointment on my face and charged me for what I ate - half a sandwich. I'm not afraid of eating a lot at lunch and I was looking forward to a full belly, but I won't finish something I'm not enjoying.   With all this neighborhood has to offer, why would anyone spend a dime on a sandwich that doesn't meet even the most modest expectations of flavor?  One star for a perceptive server.

8ahguXNS9FJjDwPynFr4gQ.review_text: Now, if you want a great panini sandwich this is where to go.  The sandwiches on foccacia bread are the best with a tall glass of Stella beer.  Above all, the best we delight ourselves in is .... the grilled  "Eggplant" sandwich.  Their salads are good but not as good as Mocca Cafe.   Coffee "Cappuccino's are THE BEST!!  Dessert's are soooo good and made homemade.  Try the Ricotta Cheesecake and not to mention the Coffee Cake. The Merlot house wine is not good. The wine selections are just ok.  They have great music playing loud and they change it often.  Yes, it is a small place but you won't regret it. The service is kinda a slow and yes it depends who's working the shift. For two people, about $35.00 to $40.00. This is way better than Mocca Cafe, still I love those tri tip sandwiches. Remember, you are getting the best quality homemade everything.  I just love Mario's, We treat ourselves so often there.   I love these places 'coz I make these at home and just as tasty, thats why I find it worth spending your hard earned $ for what you pay when you do dine out ...... it has to be GOOD!!

hs49qaQtTkiiUk1GWvNDkw.review_text: I love this place, always have.  The staff makes us feel like we are family and they know to keep the wine coming.  Even if we got into a fist fight ( Hey, I said they are like family!) I'd still keep coming back and if they had more varieties of salad...I'd never leave.

xt8tqNaVPzgBhhftXBr-5A.review_text: Such a great San Francisco establishment.  Set right across the street from Washington Square Park with huge windows to watch over North Beach.  They have cheap wine and great focaccia sandwiches.  The kind of place you go and realize how great of a city San Francisco is.

ppiZAoXF0p6DBvNRt1UcwQ.review_text: Ciao! I love the chicken sandwich #1 with a Peroni, Anchor or a glass of Montepulciano!  Buona Sera!

gEI2dgZSa-JD-3gVOHjVgA.review_text: Best spot in Little Italy.  Great people/service and top tasting food. They have a true coffee machine! Their deserts are made home made from the true Italian owners.  A++

3gxZfCVPp7HNMutb-eLchQ.review_text: In need of a solid panini? This is the place to hit. I had the mozerella, tomato and basil pesto panini and it was scrumpcious! Grilled to perfection and hit the spot after a sweet workout. This place is a cool little spot. Not too big and every table including the bar area was full. I took a peak at the drink menu and both beer and wine were very cheap. I see myself returning without a doubt. The staff carries a sense of humor and you will definitely be entertained.

PluuoC0vKMq_159qjFiR-A.review_text: A Iconic sandwich and cocktail pit stop while wandering through North Beach. The place has an alluring smell from the years of caked on grease on the one deck oven that sits at one end of the bar. It's a nostalgic smell that always delivers memories of foggy & rainy days in North Beach, where we ducked in here to escape the weather and have a drink.

Or65RHS0Shmuw7tAwoLJkg.review_text: if you are looking a great sandwich, Mario's got it.  It has the best paninis and other baked dishes.  although food comes rather slow given the number of customers the two cooks serve.

zigzaCWeF8ooSeRsksmn0g.review_text: My absolute favorite place in all of North Beach to enjoy a glass of wine and a light meal at an affordable cost.  We always eat at the bar where you can watch them make your food and take in the whole room.  We like the lasagna, the eggplant parmigiana and anything made with the foccacia (it's from Liguria).    Service is always friendly.  You come here to relax, not for a fast meal - if you want that, please go to In 'n Out Burger down at Fisherman's Wharf.

emIVSls-1hbkPIf4QeEDkg.review_text:
"The best sandwich I have EVER had." You must go to Mario's and have the Chicken #2. Sit outside and drink some wine-- just be sure you get the one table with sunshine.
  UPDATE!!!!!
  So I have been to Mario's twice since this review and the Chicken #2 was lame... Still love the ambiance. Looks like I am going to have to order something new next time.

OsUxhCIgxRxF5cu6Z4_dLw.review_text: The food is really decent, and the location can't be beat.  The wine selection is a joke, and served in juice cups.  I get that is authentic, but they could do better.  Drinking bad wine out of a crappy cup doesn't work.    I would give them four stars, except for their shitty, arrogant service.  Who the hell do those hipsters think they are?  They belong in the Mission, not North Beach, which is a friendly place for cool, normal people.  I don't think the waitstaff understands why they are getting small tips.  It's because you're assholes!

TuFsdCB7HzJ4eigRQQYNbw.review_text:
This is the spot in North Beach where my friends from Napoli like to go, bypassing all the touristy pretend-Italian joints that predominate on Columbus ave.  
  For the love of god, try the meatball panini (of if you don't eat meat, the fried eggplant panini is a close second choice).  The foccacia is baked fresh daily right around the corner and it's fantastic.  Get your panini, a bottle of peroni, and watch through the window all the people walking by washington square.

qQa9J0fXA6E-3JSFNsF7TA.review_text: Decent sandwich - I had the grilled chicken #1 - the foccacia was perfect and good enough to eat by itself. I was dissapointed it didn't come with any sides - fries would've been nice or even a bag of chips. It did come with pepperoncinis which I absolutely love. They got gobbled up before I even started on the sandwich.   The establishment is quite small so if it's just you and a friend you'll be fine but anymore than that and space will become a premium.  I hear the meatball sandwich is crazy good.

oo8fs0VCoyQfhD9PKmGmig.review_text: I'm 35, I've had my share of Meatball sandwiches during my life.  This is by far the best Meatball sandwich I have ever had.  I live in Chicago, 2,135 miles from Marios, its rough.  By the way, they have the smallest bathroom ever, its crazy.

UQcjPecs1-vvr2Ut0fh6ow.review_text: it pains me to give mario's a glowing review b/c i want to be able to grab a seat next time i go by.  cram yourself into a tiny table inside, belly up to the bar, or brave the san francisco weather at one of the outdoor seats with a view of columbus ave and washington square park.  order a seriously delicious sandwich and watch your quality of life improve instantly.  years ago i sat at one of the tight little tables  (in the pointy corner of the store where columbus ave meets union st)  with my then friend and now husband.  cozy spaces are seriously romantic (at any time of day).  my girlfriend's have told me of "special moments" with a date here.  it must be the no-pressure, un-assuming atmoshphere that allows people to relax with each other.  the only downside for me is that the coffee is lack luster.  i know mario's gets it's coffee from the local coffee roaster (so it's super fresh) but it's not quite as good as you get from some of the other coffee bars in the neighborhood (there's no shortage).  maybe their machine needs to be "calibrated" or tweeked, i should give it another try.  it's worth it.

TZExGajxC02oetl7iQ77eg.review_text: Mario's sandwiches, selection and service has been on a downward slide for a couple of years now.  Their formerly nice selection of ports has been narrowed to "tawny" and "red" - one of each.  The last four sandwiches I've ordered there have been served either over or under cooked, and staff is careless.  Sad to see the old place slide.  Hoping they can reverse the trend.

y7oeeuOub0p-ih5Olbct2A.review_text: This is a cute little corner cafe! Love the tiramisu here. Right across from the cathedral and Washington Square....  Get a tiramisu and a coffee/tea and just people watch :)

W46UkrAvPokkWfXno1cD6g.review_text: I have been sitting on this review for awhile, agonizing if I was going to give it 4 or 5 stars. And then it hit me: The focaccia sandwiche(s) that I have had here has become the end-all be-all sandwich to which I compare all other sandwiches.   In the last couple of weeks, every time I eat a sandwich (which seems to be fairly frequently at the moment), I catch myself saying, "It's good, but it's not as good as Mario's." It has set the upper limit of my sandwich scale. If that's not reason enough to give this place 5 stars, I don't know what is.   Not surprisingly, I think the secret is the bread itself - perfectly crunchy but still soft. If you want something that can only be ironically described as "health," I suggest the salami/ham sandwich.   To. Die. For.   The service is a little...strange. They are nice and try to be funny, but come off as just a little awkward. It's really hard for me to put my finger on it, as they are attentive and not rude, but just...different.   Bottom line, even if the service was the most horrendous thing in the history of the world, the sandwiches would make up for it x20. Definitely a must when in Northbeach.

QQ_Wg6ZiLhiG0WHtLdnY2A.review_text: I've spent way too much time in this little shop looking out onto washington square park!  My favorite table is the one in the very corner, looking out on both Columbus and Union Streets.  Get a focaccia sandwich - grilled chicken #2, meatball, veggie are all truly notable - and an italian soda.  Give yourself a while though - the customer service is friendly but lackadaisical.

k6CQ4HbIC1hGCTbhVjgXCA.review_text: We loved this place when we visited for lunch a few Mondays back.  Food was excellent.  The Rollie Fingers look a like needs to quit his job as a waiter though.  He certainly did not look like he enjoys it.  Other staff was great.  It is a small place and overall, awesome!

ut0JV6-7t9NVP4lJqz36_A.review_text: Ohhh yeah snap into a beard. These guys ooze man-hood. never mind the the north biatch. a spicy meatball will satifies me. love the boys at maaarios.

tMvJ3MgOGUw2X5KGkmC1Gg.review_text: I love this place - whenever I am in San Francisco, Mario's is like my compass. I have found myself on a barstool eating an eggplant focaccia panini and drinking some house wine several times and I couldn't have been happier.  Falling into Mario's is like leaving 21st century earth and landing into 1974 (as I imagine it).  It just feels right.  Oh, hey, and their bathroom ~ you will never visit another one like it, I promise...

8k3aO-mPeyhbR5HUucA5aA.review_text: Mario's was a cigar store 50 years ago but not now, it's an eatery with expresso, pizza, sammies, beer, and .a few bottles of wine. seating is at a bar and a few tables.  review is of the coffee only.  brew: americano (2) -full body, edgy,  freshly brewed,  -thatsa italian!  drips: -biz looked slow on a saturday morn. -even found parking in north beach, so rare.

D1Wbw8tlt8sNCq049No5pA.review_text: Good food, not great when I was there, but the prices are fair.  Nice location next to the park. Drinking a soju on the rocks was my favorite course of the meal :)

_xVqtBEIBS2nTffGl9UrUQ.review_text: Tasty inexpensive sandwiches on foccacia made from the tiniest sandwich station on the planet! Super good tho.  Can get pretty crowded.

XOrMnYsmiSj54ivFrAsK3A.review_text: The mozzarella panini is amazing. Takes a bit for them to prepare but, oh man, it is well worth the wait.

ss1PGLjfjitXP2o0_95SCA.review_text: This place is better than an average sandwich joint and beats the Subway 5 for 5 for sure.  I once did an engagement photo session here since the couple met here and that was fun!  It is charming and service great and truly good food.

JnGtgOPpkjyWOvWM0SYEXg.review_text: local north beach sandwich 'n' pizza bar....weekend stroll down the corner for a sluggish meal to come....one cook oven action....construction...oven bake...out..finishin' slice and plate....filled and cozy....sip on a soda, brew o' coffee....awaiting sausage..others awaiting eggplant, meatball 'n' more....wait..wait...wait...wait...waiting~~~~...­patience necessary....  surprising good sandwiches.....meaty 'n' fillin'....tasting great 'n' final product actually above satisfactory.....only small questioning of sanitation of bread piled open on bookshelf corner wall....

AxJNQAe5DVEIcSdOSOo3Yg.review_text: Meatball Sandwich to die for...: Went for a lunch of the meatball sandwich and an iced tea. Handsome waiter that I made smile and the sandwich truly surprised me. The meatballs are cut in half and packed tightly in sauce and cheese between triangles of foccacia bread. Got quite a bit of writing done and had a great view of a guy playing Frisbee with his son in the park.

KgDOK0iFpD2mQsKkpvrALg.review_text: My favorite hang out in the North Beach!  A small lil joint at the butt end of NB.  The floors are wooden and busted.  The entire place is rather triangular making the restaurant a bit oddly laid out.  I enjoy places with a lot of charm and you can tell this place has a long history of it.  I mean, there has to be some story behind why a hot sandwich shop is called a Cigar Store!    My favs are the meatball sandwich and the open faced tuna melt.   Most of the sandwiches are oven heated so the foccacia are nicely toasted with a crispy crunch to it.  Crumbs crumbs everywhere and I lick my fingertip to pick up every bit I could find on my shirt!  The must in all meals here is the coffee (bottomless btw).  I usually dump a lot of cream in my coffees, but Mario's coffee doesn't require much.  It's pure silk on it's own!    -1 star for inconsistent service.  Some days I could be utterly ignored, and other times they'd be by your side once you pick up a menu.  Your best bet is dining at the bar area where you can just shout your order to the oven master!

1eS6uvwDUv8d5fMbbfZNOQ.review_text: Good coffee, good food, good atmosphere, good location.  I wish they had more outdoor tables.  I disagree with the info on Yelp about this place that says it isn't good for kids.  I see babies and kids here with parents frequently and they all seem to be having a fine time.

t9cze1D9Gb8d-spMoHHSSg.review_text: This is a fun place to just hang out and their sandwiches are the best. They use foccacia bread (very yummy). We had the #1 chicken sandwich and the combo. The sausage and the meatball sandwiches are also very delicious. Great No beach hangout!

YbZg36FoMgkKcTEPae5siA.review_text: I've stopped by here on numerous occasions and I've always had a good meal. The sandwiches and pizza are just the right amount for the right price and the staff have always been great.  This last time I stopped in I came and sat at the bar as a lone diner with a book. I ordered my food and the bartender noticed that my nose kept running. I thought it was due to allergies. He brought me a port with hot water in it because he said, "This is what I have when my nose is running." Sure enough, it cleared up my nose for the entire day. I'm sure if I didn't bury myself in my book there would've been much more chatting going on. I'll have to thank him for the runny nose cure and catch his name next time I stop in. I didn't feel rushed but since it was starting to get busy I figured I should get going since I had finished eating.  I know this place is small so I never bring more than 3 other people with me max. I like that it has a cozy feel to it that a lot of places these days seem to lack.  You won't find cigars here but you'll find a lot of regulars who just want to have a drink or a quick no frills meal. The prices have gone up a little bit since I've been going here but I think that's expected in a city such as this one and it's way more reasonable than a lot of other places along Columbus.

09XgrUKILZklJGlBT6cJ8g.review_text: Ok so I had one day in San Fransisco and decided to try out this place and I'm so glad I did.   It's a small place. 10 people can sit at the bar and there are about 10 tables.   There is no back kitchen. If you're sitting at the bar, you can watch them make your food. Right behind the counter is where they prep everything in a big fire oven.   When you ask for a sub, that's when they throw in the dough in their oven and the break bakes right then and there.   We tried the meatball sandwich and it's one of the best I've had (and I have tried maaaany meatball subs) and the grilled chicken salad. Both greaaaaat.   The cakes sitting at the counter were hard to resist but i somehow did.  Having said that... I'm taking a star off because the staff can be a bit moody (not rude..just kinda cranky) and slow at times. I waited 10 minutes to see if they will ever refill my coffee (i was sitting right across from 2 workers at the bar) and then gave up and asked for it. I didn't mind their personalities it as much as someone else might.

lGF_5chfdvtGHoFwmM6yCQ.review_text: Before I lambaste this place I need to qualify my scathing review by admitting that I'll be back.  The only reason is that they serve Graffeo Coffee, which is easily the best stuff within a 100 mile radius.  Okay, now I can proceed to blast this place.  Let me begin by explaining that my tiff is with the waitstaff.  They have a server who is worthless and a bartender who works at a pace that rivals the speed at which grass grows.  We walked in the door on a nice Saturday afternoon and it wasn't really all that busy.  We went to the bar where we were ignored for about 5 minutes.  This server was waiting on one of the tables inside, we make eye contact, and then a table opened up outside which we promptly nabbed.  After being ignored for another 10 minutes the same server comes outside and walks past us.  I quickly asked him if he could grab us some menus as we still hadn't been served, and this guy has the nerve to suggest that I "go inside and get them at the bar" because the Sultan himself is "on a break."  Yea that guy is a complete turd burglar.    Anyhow, I walk inside and up to the bar, I ask the bartender for the menu and she says she'll be right with me.  Another 5 minutes go by - NO EXAGGERATION.  This chic was actually moving about as fast as a glacier - and she served several other people who came after me... and all I asked for was a menu.  What the hell is wrong with these people?

4vPenosP7mMkADQLhfLHGg.review_text: I just love this place.  It is true to itself: a cozy, local neighborhood joint that has been around for decades and serves up non-fancy fare at decent prices.  No, it won't be the best meal you've eaten, but it will be reasonably priced and fill you up.  A great place to meet friends for a casual low-key impromptu dinner.  We don't have nearly enough places like Mario's in SF these days.

VpREWOjt5Pna6OIgXI9Jcg.review_text: Despite the enticing aroma of garlic and sauces all hereabouts, I normally run screaming from any food establishment in North Beach. I've only had bland meals with fine-dining prices in this part of town, so I tend to leave Steps of Rome and their ilk to the tourists.  But Mario's has me wondering whether I've been a bit hasty.  Similar to Cafe Francisco a few blocks up, Mario's is good for a quality lunch. Also like Cafe Francisco, it's a wee bit expensive (in the $10 range), but they do have table service. I came with a co-worker, and we both had paninis, mine with chicken and avocado and the right amount of cheese. The sandwiches are on the small side, but I usually try to avoid food-coma-inducing lunches anyway.  Cozy interior, cute decor, be-Diesel-ed staff (maybe they're all actually Italian?), and a view of Washington Square Park to go with the meal ain't so bad at all.  Oh, and I don't know if they actually have cigars, but I don't think those would go well with panini.

OfBxv_lindDyWpqyvK_pzw.review_text: Food: 4.5 stars Service: 4 stars Value: 4 stars  We came to the city to meet our friends for Saturday brunch. They took us to this little cafe by Washington park. My friends said this cafe was very old-fashioned, authentic and yummy. And man, it was true!   I was amazed by their delicious hot sandwiches and pizza. The price was about $9 each, which was pretty average in the city.   The waiter was good and make sure we were happy with food and drinks. I highly recommend this place if you ever stop by the Little Italy area in the city.

m-45HDQiH2uIL1dbR6fJUw.review_text: Very cool place, never changes. Quintessential old North Beach. Fried eggplant sandwiches and drinks are great!

NINonEafvhz3Z1tF0rtmWA.review_text: Delicious! great service and relaxed atmosphere.  I need to come back and try more items and write a longer review.

zcUcJAU9Hiah9R5-UZWOug.review_text: Their sandwiches are soo filling! You can eat half and you will already be SUPER filled. This isn't a cigar store, I do not know why they even call it that. I think this place is really old because the place looks quite old. The staff was really nice, a lot of recommendations from them. The place is quite small and the tables are too. Their pizzas are good! Thin crust, I wished they would put more cheese. The food that I orders seem to take quite a long time to come!!

IxKjgqLAG6teY_pqGnh9ZQ.review_text: Just got back from a coffee/hot chocolate date on this beautiful, almost-sunny Sunday morning :-)!  I've lived in North Beach for almost a year and I'm sad to say that I have not been to Mario's until today.  It's a really cool cafe with great atmosphere and a great place for people watching -- straight out the window are the outstanding view of  St. Peter & Paul Church and Washington Square Park.    The place is small, but not only do they have coffee and pastries, they  also have a good selection of salads, hot foccacia sandwiches, panini, pizza, lasagna, eggplant parm and beers (on-tap and bottle).    Service is good... attentive, friendly and funny.  Don't ask for whipped creme on your hot chocolate because, "that's not how we roll at Mario's," according to one of the servers.  The bathroom is tiny, if you stand over 5-foot tall, I do not think you'll be able to use it.    After finishing up our hot beverages, we were served a short-glass of sparkling h2o with lemon, which I thought was perfect. Too bad you cannot smoke cigars in here, but there are cigars available for purchase.    I will be back again.

l3znAei9pbBJiLK9IxnwSw.review_text: This is one of those joints that I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here, but since I'm in the area and I don't want to drive or walk super far, might as well.  Try the pastrami panini - it's a solid choice.

m07sy7eLtOjVdZ8oN9JKag.review_text: We're talking about casual eats in a classic setting (see my photos). This place probably represents the third corner of the North Beach triad that includes Caffe Trieste and Victoria's Pastry Company. OK, maybe you have to add Caffe Sport and Steps of Rome. OK, maybe not Steps of Rome because they lick your neck there. Well, not mine, but Rachael Ray's, I think, on that $40-a-Day-Cause-I'm-Too-Rich-to-Tip show. Oh my gravy.  But back to Mario's. Big bar, little tables inside, a few more outside. Lots of Italian-style atmosphere - bottles of Chianti against the wall, a picture of a boccie ball player, those old artful advertising posters you see at Z Gallerie. Yet again sparked by a complete stranger's adoration of this place on "Check Please! Bay Area", Jamie W. and I went to see what the fuss was about. The menu is small but focused - focaccia sandwiches, paninis, three salads, a few pizzas, some lasagna, some eggplant parmigiana, and a few desserts. That's it.  We went for splitting two paninis, both in the $7.50-$8.50 range (see my photos). The verdict is that the salami was really good, and the chicken one a little too dry. But the bread was nice and crunchy. It comes with no extras except for a couple of pepperoncinis - which was a bit disappointing since I never turn down fries. We decided to order the $6 Caprese, which consisted of four thick, somewhat unripened tomato slices with a slab of mozzarella and a dollop of fresh basil pesto (see my photo). All in all, it's a good snack place but nothing much more than that except for a great spot overlooking Washington Square.  FOOD - 3 stars...good, toasty paninis but nothing extraordinary here AMBIANCE - 4 stars...feels like a good paisan's hangout SERVICE - 3.5 stars...friendly enough, not as indifferent as I was expecting TOTAL - 3 stars...the small servings bring this one down a little...also the easy-to-screw-up name with three nouns in a row...make up your mind!

m9oL5PQ_Sjqpmgqe85qvSA.review_text: My husband and i love this place.  it is very relaxed and has the feel of a place that has been around forever, which it has been.  In a good way.  I always get the breaded eggplant focaccia sandwich.  We have been going to this place since before they had a menu.  the sandwiches are just as good as they have always been hot, toasted perfectly.  My husbaND likes the eggplant pizza.  Together with a glass of wine or a beer on tap it makes for a very easy dinner on the nights we are too lazy to cook.  thank you, Mario's! Don't ever change.

z7C7pheG7hujTylgvag9OQ.review_text: Oh wow!  I am sitting here beginning the digestion of one of the yummiest sandwiches ever eaten!   I got the eggplant open faced half sandwich. I wish I'd gotten the full now ( even though I don't need it! ) because the tastes are extraordinary.   I'm a bit of a food snob vegetarian and a little sick of people lack of creativity when it comes to veggie dishes. They're usually eggplant or portobello mushroom based... And I usually boycott them as a result of their blandness and ubiquitousness. I am so glad that I didn't here! I would highly recommend this sandwich to anyone... Veggie and meat eaters alike.   Also there a nice view of the park and the church is just eclipsed behind a willow tree.   The ambiance is low key and the price are very reasonable. The bartenders are pleasant but a bit distant.  I will be returning, hungrier, and for the full sandwich!!! The beer's not bad either!

u6ms8jCUMd3qhlB6hufV-w.review_text: This was the worst groupon-type experience I've ever had, and the worst restaurant experience I've had. Truth be told, it's one of the worst ways I've  been treated as a human being, hands down.  Our dinner was fine. Service was abrupt, but not so much that we would make a fuss. When the bill comes, I show him the coupon on my homerun app. The night manager at Mario's flips. He tells me that it's no good, he'll only accept printed, that I should have told him when I came in. He starts screaming in the middle of the restaurant and caps it off by simulating slapping me in the face.   Let's be clear how offensive this is. I've a women in my twenties. He's a man in his forties. And he just simulated slapping me in front of 15 people because I had the gall to use a prepaid coupon his restaurant had volunteered to offer.  In my opinion, he stopped just short of assault, and I absolutely felt unsafe and threatened while in their restaurant.  I'm disgusted that this is the way we were treated for patronizing his restaurant with a prepaid coupon that his restaurant agreed to. And by bringing friends who spent double what the coupon was worth.  None of us will ever be returning, which is a shame because I really loved this place and despite not living in the neighborhood made it a point to come several times a year and recommended it to many friends. I'll never make that mistake again.

DXHSUpeuGsFczkdRVxuKtg.review_text: On a recent excursion into the city my husband and our dear friend thought it would be nice to have a cigar and a cappuccino while watching the world go by in North Beach.    Now, all of us are from the greater Bay area, so we aren't exactly tourists from the Midwest or anything, but we aren't exactly experts on San Francisco either, so we didn't really have a clue as where to start looking for cigars, and seeing that none of us are so touristy that we read guidebooks, we had absolutely no clue that this place did not actually sell cigars anymore...oops...our bad, but this small oversight does not excuse the absolutely rancid behavior of the resident bartender....  We walked in and stood at the bar for about five minutes where we waited for the bartender to look up from the wine glass he was cleaning to acknowledge our existence.  He never does look up and give us eye contact but he finally asked us if we "needed a menu or something."  Our friend asked to see the cigar selection and the bartender snapped "we don't sell cigars and we haven't sold them for over fifteen years."  We then asked him if he would happen to know of any place nearby that does sell cigars and the bartender gets even more visibly annoyed by our mere presence and snaps, again without even looking up to acknowledge our existence "NO, I DON'T---there isn't a single cigar shop in North Beach!"  At that point we decided we didn't even want to bother with ordering a glass of water from this jerk, so we hightailed it out of there, all three of us swearing that we would never step foot in that place again.    Now I realize that our lack of knowledge about this place did make us look like a group of idiotic tourists, but that's still no excuse for treating us like second-class citizens...and even if we had been Midwestern tourists there still isn't any excuse...I realize that tourists can be annoying and I make fun of them just as often as everyone else, but still...behavior like that is just uncalled for, no matter if someone is a tourist or not...  Anyhow, our experience was so unpleasant I doubt we will ever step foot back into this place...  And to the bartender with the slicked-back dark hair and goatee---you are a jerk and I suggest you brush up on your customer service skills.

LBTp89k-qNO4UY5-zsI7nw.review_text: 4 stars for the really great location, atmosphere, and comfy setting.  However, the eggplant parmesana was disappointing but after reading the reviews sounds like the thing to order there are the sandwiches.  It's still a great cafe and I'll definitely be returning but will stick to the drinks and sandwiches...and of course desserts.

Uftwnhj_yWzCZC7JEK0VHg.review_text: Classic, friendly neighborhood spot. There are always a bunch of regulars at the bar. Their open-faced, hot foccacia sandwiches are delicious and I love how their wine is served in carafes. The staff is extremely cool and efficient. One of my favorite neighborhood cafes.

zP9HLd5nwdpHXhO2rKXjEw.review_text: Frommer's includes a stop here during Day 1 of San Francisco and who are we to disagree? We were quickly seated and told that the kitchen was backed up - a nice touch. We ordered drinks, a half salad and two sandwiches: mom and I split a meatball and K got an eggplant.  The dressing on the salad was a little odd but the lettuce was great. The sandwiches were good but very different from the East Coast version on which I grew up: they use Swiss cheese here, a really different twist. Both servers were incredibly nice local hipsters who clearly cared about the job they were doing and answered our initial barrage of questions about the beer on the menu with which we weren't familiar.   Very good way to break up the day!

B6xxXHebsWphZe4_uXi3pw.review_text: Sandwiches on focaccia are the best here!  Veggie or Sausage are my favorite.  A little messy, but well worth it.   It's very reasonably priced - and always a great casual place to eat and drink.

08mOpJRCpZe3D8UHszP4FA.review_text:
I like eating there when it's not very busy otherwise you just have to have patience cuz it's a bit of a wait.  They only have a small oven and it takes time to make your sandwich.  I got a meatball sandwich to go..it came out to be $9.22 that's with tax, pricey right?!!  In the past I had a cappucino which I liked, $2.25.
  they take credit card, God bless them.

2UcWRvyQDYlVh_4pOfYd5g.review_text: I always say that I never give out 5 stars unless I am willing to call someone and tell them about a place. This is one of those places.  I love Mario's because of it's authenticity and its history. The place has been around for many many decades and you can tell. They have amazing sandwiches (esp the chicken focaccia). They also have good selection of wines and their cappuccino's are excellent.  Above all else, it's a neighborhood spot. I love going in and sitting in the corner table and writing for hours. During the day you can people watch as they walk through North Beach or play in Washington Square park. The people who work there are all very interesting and great conversationalists. Almost as an art form. On nice weekend days, they open doors on both sides of the establishment to get a great cross breeze and an influx of neighborhood characters.  CLINCHER - They play the best music. I discovered Calexico here - one of my favorite bands  ONLY COMPLAINT - no wi-fi... then again, what restaurant/bar does right? Bad for turnover I guess

DEtFNQFuUphOVcgD2Kbn6A.review_text: This isn't "fancy" Italian food. But it's honest and satisfying. My favorite is their lasagna, an unpretentious mix of noodles, rich tomato sauce, goopy mozzeralla cheese, and ground beef. Salty, fatty, meaty goodness. Sometimes, when I'm elsewhere eating fancy lasagna, I wish it were this.   The space is small and cozy and has nice views of the nearby church and park. It's a great place to read a book and sip some wine.

xpRAjmgL-pIcIY_9iOpcQw.review_text: Cramped, loud, piss-poor wine selection but an all-time favorite.  If you haven't had the focaccia sandwiches, you really haven't lived.  Go with a friend, get one meatball and one sausage and go "halfsies."  Otherwise if you get the meatball you're going to wish you'd gotten the sausage, and vice versa.  And don't let 'em be stingy with the pepperoncini...they'll try but don't let 'em.

k3Ter4z5RGBuPGeTVt067Q.review_text: This used to be a great cafe overlooking Washington Square park. However, as other reviewers have noted, the 'hipster' staff appear to see customers more as an annoyance. Service SUCKS...especially if you grab a table outside. We waited 30 minutes and still had not ordered a drink. When I went in to order the food myself the rude barman said "I won't take your order  - that's why we have a waitress". When I questioned waiting 30 minutes, he said. "We'll get to you when we are ready". At that point we left. Seriously....there are too many good choices in the neighborhood - my advice, skip the attitude and try one of the other cafés instead.

PtK1p7dF6k4ljUivjLdALg.review_text: Good paninis. Nice location across from the park.

he4K1UtoD4Su54SbCoFkUw.review_text: Give me the sun in washington square and a Chicken #2 sammy and I'm happy. as long as the chicken is cooked right. I give Mario's 3 only, only because the quality of food can be hit or miss. At times the food can be over cooked, dry etc. Pizzas included, and other times, i'd say the majority, the food is killer and its a great addition to a day is washington square.

YEB1pj90TVwomI97OBqPKQ.review_text: Great sandwiches and salads.  The place is small.  The staff is friendly and fast.  Good atmosphere.  I've not had anything bad here.  Anything on their foccacia is good.  I love the eggplant, my children and husband love the meatball and chicken sandwiches.  Their coffees and expressos are outstanding.  I feel compelled to consume quickly and get out to make room for others, and there's always someone waiting for our table.

4dclJLG4cO_ACx2zkCbjag.review_text: This is a great place to eat lunch or take it out and eat it in Washington Square Park (on one of the few days San Francisco is nice to you and the sun shines).   I will order anything with the dijon mustard on it and Chicken #1 and the meatball sandwiches are my favorites! It takes awhile for them to make your sandwich (about 10 minutes if they're not that busy), but it's worth the wait. The foccacia bread they put the sandwich on is so good.  The cheesecake was kind of a disappointment though. It kind of tasted like thick egg bread and wasn't what I expected at all.

QqcWKvwLBzXKLqdJnbbgAg.review_text: Came here for lunch today with some co-workers since we work really close by! It's a cute little cafe with a catchy name and I've been wanting to try this place! I ordered the breaded eggplant sandwich while my coworkers ordered lasagna, chicken salad, and polenta & sausage. After taking a few bites of my eggplant sandwich, I ended up opening it up so I can add in some salt & pepper. It was a little too bland for my taste, in which one of my coworkers agreed also. As for the breaded eggplant, it was thinner than I thought it would be! If I do come back, maybe I will try a pizza instead next time!

hVm6iln51tI4gkM5o5PbOA.review_text: Food is very nice - A little overpriced for the sandwiches and 'weak' italian soda's, but it is San Francisco after all. What lets this place down is the service - or lack thereof. I realize when things are busy the servers might take longer to take an order or check on you, but today was the final straw. Considering I have been here a few times before, I expected to wait five minutes for the staff to acknowledge me, but twenty minutes of sitting outside and I still didn't have a menu, glass of water or any awareness that I was there. Indeed other folks on the five tables outside also seemed rather confused (this is a tourist area). Once I did get service, the waitress had a serious attitude - as if I had somehow inconvenienced her somehow. Seriously....she's a waitress...that's her job. Even better if she has a smile on her face. But no...By the time I got the check, I just wanted to get out of there.  To the management of Mario's: Your service is getting worse. I for one won't be back, and judging from some other reviews, the hipster attitude is alienating your regular customers. Believe me...when the tourists leave, its the locals who keep your restaurant in business.  Shame....but there are too many other places to get coffee and a sandwich who make your feel welcome.

2nBPGg56am7XoOdGR4tofg.review_text: This is a cool and cozy place to get something to eat and drink in a fun location with great people watching across from Washington Square park. The food is simple, but really tasty and satisfying. The meatball sandwich is great, and my personal favorite is the lasagna (which I am always a sucker for, no matter where I am). Every time I get Mario's lasagna, I am presented with a bubbling dish of gooey, cheesy, meaty, tomatoey goodness. Again, it's all pretty simple stuff, but it really hits the spot. Add to that a beer or glass of wine with a view of the (hilarious, in my opinion) segway tours that often pass by outside, and you've got it made.

SpNerb3jINdfMvpN-4L5PA.review_text: Not all of us ordered food, but those that did were really satisfied. We had lasagna, which had a bit of a sweet flavor to it. My fave dish of the night, the oven baked meatball sammy with swiss cheese, onions, and marinara on onion focaccia bread. The focaccia, which came highly recommended lived up to the hype. The crunch of the bread combined with melted cheese and warm sauce was a great combination. We also had the grilled chicken #1 sammy- dijon mustard, pepper jack cheese, and onions on the amazing focaccia bread. This one was good too. I had the caprese salad- fresh mozzarella, sliced tomatoes, and fresh basil pesto. This was tasty, the pesto was awesome. Mario's is priced right, the service is excellent, and the food is terrific. For a more detailed review visit: consumingcolumbus.blogsp…

mLSmllyXR9psRMFqQiET8Q.review_text: Gem of a find.  Small and friendly, best lunch experience I had on my entire San Francisco trip.  The pastrami was beautiful...

aYATgajrWIiL8be0Ty-CbQ.review_text: On our adventure through Little Italy we stopped by Mario's because we heard they had a mean meatball sandwich.   We walked in, and I don't know if the girl working there could tell we were tourists but I got a weird vibe from her. Like this was a local spot and she didn't know what we were doing there. Or maybe it was just her being an awkward hipster girl...I'm not quite sure. Either way, I didn't get a good vibe. Since we had already been exploring elsewhere we ordered one sandwich to go.   When we got to the hotel we finally started grubbing. The sandwich was very good! It was melty, gooey and flavorful. The cheese, meat, veggies and sauce went well together.  If it was based solely on the sandwich this place would be a 4 stars, but because of the snobby girl, I'm giving it a 3. Oh, wellll.

neL0eerLKJXPmWqxDjNIWQ.review_text: Gah. I hate to do this. I really do. I wanted to like you Mario, but you just weren't for me. Maybe it was the rainy dreary weather. The hunger. The thoughts that kept drifting to Liguria's or Mama's or even Tartine's in the Mission... Whatever it was, this didn't match up.  I was determined to try a new place in North Beach since I had been to a couple of the places already. Liguria's- good. That other place on the corner that was pretty un-rememberable that I don't remember the name- not that special. But, I was yelping and I had just dropped off stuff in Chinatown to get altered, so I thought I would try the paninis here. In truth, they were okay. The bread was okay and the toppings okay.  A pretty good "half sandwich" for 5.50. Turkey for my mom, veggie for me. But bland sir, bland for my taste. I was hoping for some interesting spread or quirky cheese to spice it up, but it was just...okay. I had this eggplant affixation, but alas this place did not relieve me.  However, on the upside, probably one of the best mochas I've had. So go there for the drinks. Or at least the mocha.

8p-kv82J5uP3583thTPa4Q.review_text: the meat ball sammich is still the best!, that is all.

pAGSv-8vo6k6hpgqw_fIdA.review_text: Yay Meatball! Cheap Italian style food in North Beach? Yes! It exists! Mario's is a great place to get an affordable tasty meal, have a drink, and oogle all the people as they pass by Columbus Ave. I highly recommend the Meatball Sandwich. I think it's the only thing worth ordering. mmm. Pilsner and Meatball.

4DWrjufPQW7Xeb-HgsVU3g.review_text: I was going to say I was unimpressed with the size of the panini sandwich. But then I did some research and found out panini is the plural of panino which translates to "small bread". So egg on my face.   So instead I'll say the panini is good and I am really anxious to try some of the bigger varieties of sandwiches. A panini is more a snack you and a friend would share as you take advantage of the beers on tap.   But the real draw is the Americano. So far the best I have had in SF. I know it is just espresso and hot water, but beyond Starbucks it's tough to find good ones and Mario's Americano is great.   I just love the fact you can get an espresso drink and a biscotti or other dessert or load up on carbs with beer and Italian food. Or both in the same day if you plan it right (one of these days).   And the location right on Washington Square is unbeatable. Considering 90% of Columbus Ave is tourist traps, Mario's is a must see European style cafe, even down to the slow service. But hey, why are you in a hurry in North Beach?

2NuzVdjq89uIOCwRzEHeFQ.review_text: Mario's is a great place to hang out on a rainy afternoon or evening. It's a neighborhood spot - tourists tend to stay out.   I simply haven't found a better meatball sandwich, ever. The other items on the menu are good. The pizzas are nice. But I only eat the meatball sandwich.

PGo2u9t4sLCg9tEpbFXMtA.review_text: This was my first visit to Mario's. I tried this place on a whim and was very impressed. I ordered the Combo sandwich which was perfectly toasted. I also ordered a glass of wine to go along. Thanks Marios

Qkr_FLR4eLftWT294dpjlw.review_text: Best focaccia sandwiches, great espresso, and a variety of beers and wines. Good music. Hip spot, and lovely view of WA Square Park with Sts. Peter & Paul in the background. Been coming here since the old man owned in and the place was full of cigar-smoking men parlando italiano!

ZGiXcOTc508cAer5aZlQqg.review_text: this place makes consistently great sandwiches on focaccia bread however don't go for the service.  they have been known to be brusque.

R_aCqb62GyeU2h7OmSufeA.review_text: Best sandwich ever!  Ever!  Yes, it's really that good. Try their foccacia sandwiches, you'll be back again, and again for them. I go here about once a week. This place is my go to spot for chilling at a restaurant near the park, people watching, good sandwich eating, and having a great meal for a reasonable price. Don't expect the severs to wait on you hand and foot, but the service isn't bad either. They'll get your food and drinks to you in a reasonable amount of time, but since the place is so small they will probably be busy. You might have to wait to get a table if you come on a weekend, but if you're looking for an amazing sandwich, do yourself a favor and wait it out. It'll be worth it :)

9GHA-fDa3gIzU3WyHrdrpg.review_text: Come here if you want sandwiches and beer.  It's like a bar with tables, and without the TV.  This is the perfect Saturday lunch spot if you want to be able to just chill and get some quick food on the sorta cheap.  I live in the neighborhood, and hit it up at least twice a month.  The only food I can vouch for is the eggplant pannini and foccacia sandwich, both baked and breaded. Good stuff man, I think the arugala makes the difference... and that fine ass north beach bread.  My friends assure me that the dead animals they serve are consistently delicious as well.  Also, it's not too touristy, which is always a worry in North Beach.  They would get 4 stars but... at the end of a day it's only an eggplant sandwich,even if it is the best I have ever had. They would have to stuff that eggplant with truffles to get 5 stars from me.

OphYmSCK6VrMMXMA7AtdEQ.review_text: Great spot for people watching & having a beverage. Liked the staff - was offered a free beer, but seeing as I don't drink beer anymore and my date was doing all the driving, we declined. Food looked good.

iuM58omo8jIrLvO31w-L-g.review_text: This place is the bomb-diggity. Tasty morsels and all the right details when I want to go Italian and get my draft Anchor Steam.

slD4NzJqbv_ehv1kQa4D1A.review_text: 11/18/09 I had a delicious foccacia sandwich with grilled eggplant, $6. nice that you can choose to only get half a sandwich. I seriously could have eaten there everyday, that one taste I had was so good. Staff was nice too. I was alone, so I sat at the bar. Sad the hubby never got to eat there as he would have loved it.

HvUXiTSN-Y8raG1pqQubtQ.review_text: I brought an out of town friend here, and it was cold inside, my tea was so-so, and the food wasn't too impressive.  But it's a great place to sit and enjoy the view of the Washington Square.

vcudFvE9T6_wV-2zEA9-iw.review_text: Their meatball sub is not to be missed. Very cute hole-in-the-wall vibe, and foccacia from the bakery across the park. Seriously, their meatball sub is the best!

Fbtnt96HKD3ISMvmqGTNAg.review_text: i went back on saturday around 12:30.  it was SUPER busy and since its such a small place, it was kind of hard getting a table and service. but nonetheless, it was still delicious :) good job guys!  note: its all about timing when you come to mario's on a weekend. but its worth the wait!

686PUfFvZ-Y4b0opAUtikw.review_text: Met friends for lunch here yesterday and though I enjoyed the food and the company, I didn't get what the big deal was about these sandwiches.  Maybe if I'd had their signature sandwiches, Meatball, or Sausage, I would have had a better idea.  But, they were out of both.  So, I had the grilled chicken #2.  It was good, but, I've had just as good at other places for less money.  It's a great location, right across the street from the park, for people and dog watching, of which I enjoy.    However, I feel my friends hyped this place up too much.  So much so that my expectations were probably impossible to meet.

jxdGL90JR1b6UTvfxwW9TQ.review_text: I cannot believe that we lived 2 1/2 blocks from here and never went. Dammit.  Had to grab a quick bite before our son's concert across the park at St. Peter & Paul on a Saturday night. Sat at the counter - me, hubby, daughter. Ordered the half carafe of wine while waiting for hubby to find parking.  Daughter orders caprese and a pizza. She has pronounced it the best caprese in the world - the tomatoes were perfectly ripe, the mozzarella was the freshest she's had, and instead of just a basil leaf, they topped it with a dab of pesto which she loved.  I had the grilled eggplant half sandwich plus a salad. It was the best, most simply satisfying sandwich ever. The caesar was just fine.  Hubby also had the sausage half sandwich/salad combo and he liked his meal as well.  But what gives them the extra star(s)? Service. They were so incredibly friendly.  In fact, while we were there, one of the people associated with our concert came to get some to-go sandwiches for a few of the boys who were singing. They made them as fast as was humanly possible with only 2 guys working the whole place and most of the tables taken.  And towards the end, after we paid the check, they realized they didn't charge us for the half carafe of wine...so they apologized, brought the bottle over and filled our glasses to the top gratis, and then gave us the wine check for the original half carafe. That made me so happy because I wanted just that one more glass of wine but wasn't going to order one. I love it when people make inconsequential mistakes but have the good sense and superior customer service approach to make it an opportunity instead. They have guaranteed my return business by that simple gesture (which they didn't need to do) and this is exactly why I will be back again and again.

IH28llFlUXRfsckbxDryqg.review_text: I discovered this perfect little cafe the moment I arrived in San Francisco over a year ago now. It has served as my favorite hide-a-way in North Beach. I do my writing here as I enjoy a glass of wine and a macchiato. Ah balance.

NmWYBMJJgWpNyN7DLDVaWQ.review_text: Been eating here since the days of them selling cigars. Yeah it stunk up the plaace, but now we can reminisce how cool it was...      Look most places in North Beach are touristy traps, but the  places still original in my book are Marios and Stellas down the street. They treat you right here, are nice and by the way make good foccacia sandwiches. Hits the spot after a walk from the Embarcadero over the Filbert Steps.      They play pretty good catch with the dishes when they're done cleaning them too! Never seen em drop one!

5z2nW6VytwdX3-aEpmTRTQ.review_text: I first popped into this comfortable cafe while I was trying to avoid the drunken crowds on St. Patty's Day.  It is a great place to sip a coffee  while watching the pedestrian heavy streets of North Beach.  The table in the very corner of the wedge shaped cafe is the best seat in the house. Slip into this cozy spot on a cool and breezy San Francisco afternoon.

5eNzy6FRdxQlkiCMFBFgRg.review_text: This would be a long, glowing review if I ordered more than one thing over and over and over and over again--"The Combo" focaccia sandwich. The best hot club you can join.

BM6d18JXD4639bgRqtWc7w.review_text: Came here with my boyfriend after seeing the great reviews. We saw a few reviews that warned about the service but thought, well if the food is good who cares. After an hour and a half of waiting (with people who came much later than us receiving the same food we ordered) I was ready to get up and leave. The food came right then and I thought this better be as good as the reviews mentioned. We got a meatball sandwich and a pizza and let me tell you, it was mediocre (and I was starving so that says something). You could go to literally any other Italian cafe in this area and have something better that doesn't take an hour and a half. Oh and I forgot to mention, the servers were pretty unpleasant. Needless to say, I suggest you avoid this place.

65uUyG9yuF0rdMh0z7ajaA.review_text: All about the focaccia sandwiches. So good! Can be really slow sometimes, but absolutely worth the wait.  I really can't describe just how yummy it is.

Z4t8gv0MPl26KdeNOBov-g.review_text: I can't really be objective about Marios. I've  been going to Marios for so long -- I've known so many people who work(ed) there spanning so many eras. It's a true North Beach institution and rivals Cafe Trieste and some others in that regard. It has its 'people' and following. I can't be objective about the food or service, since I've had everything they make 1000 times and know everyone personally who works there. This place has been a home to me. And I appreciate Paulo the owner and all the various people over all the various time periods that has made Marios a part of my life.  For the unintiated, Marios is a place you go to just hang out and be merry. You have some red wine, order a pizza or a meatball sammy and talk loud and be animated or sit outside on the stockton street side between 4-6 when the sun is shining there and people watch.  Be cool with the people who work there and they will be cool with you. Tip well and they will be even cooler.  Marios hours sort of roll with how busy it is, it can be open late. In the old days it was open really late on weekends, and I still think the owner should re-consider serving food til 12:30am on Fri and Sat., as there is nothing this end of the 'hood to get a pizza when hungry late.  They selection of food is not vast, but it what it is and its consistent. This is not a place to come in being a vegan or foodie. Just be cool. Bring a cool book or some post-cards or a scrabble board or deck of cards or your flyers for your next gig or some Euro hotties you just met -- converse, hang out, see what happens -- and enjoy a beer and go on about your business. A pretty good tiramisu, carrot cake and some other treats to go with the coffee. No soy here! You want raw milk without pasteurization? I applaud you -- just don't come looking for that at Marios. This is a good old fashion real authentic north beach haunt.  Bravo!  PS Once you couldn't smoke inside anymore, they did away with the cigars -- and they finally got a credit card machine a few years back after being known for "cash only" -- i took great pleasure watching a guy on a first date sadly have to make the walk up the block to the ATM...ah, the good ole days... :-)

qYtceH6w5ZD2_CKsZCJdqQ.review_text: Cozy, Euro and very friendly. Munch on the smoked turkey foccacia sandwich while downing the smooth house red wine and plan the revolution. If you need further fortification, try their tiramisu and cappuccinos.

5xFkiPEarQUZMbUcJYz8Rg.review_text:
4.5 stars...well I can't give 5 stars all the time or you'll never believe me.
  I love this place...I'm almost a regular, but only eat lunch here about once or twice a month so that doesn't quite qualify me.
  Today a Perfect Cappucino and also a perfect Eggplant Parmagiana. I only drink coffee about once a week, so that perfect gets a capital "P"  - when you only drink coffee once in awhile, it better be good. Don't ignore the parmigiana ~ it is lovely ~ delicious and hot. Other sandwiches and caprese, etc are all very good.
  They should get that 5th star today for being so FAST! I've had a few lunchtimes where they slowed down my return to work too much and I couldn't come back for awhile.
  Two gelaterias nearby, so you're all set for dessert. Although the cakes and pies are yummy right here.
  p.s. I came here when I was very young and remember the actual cigar store! How many people can say that?!

iC7X-D9ks5u8W5jKtzttiw.review_text: i love their meatball focaccia sandwich!

Ow_oHwqaBBRuUAiNrL8rRw.review_text: I love this Place on Columbus in my favorite Neighborhood " North Beach". Small Cafe with great I mean Great Eggplant sandwiches. They are so fluffy and light and big!. They are so tasty I always get one to go.  You can sit there with some wine or beer and people watch folks on the street or St. Mary's Park. It such a great place , check it out.

jFSrZYDK85AM4Yhrbg99kg.review_text: ridiculous service!  the espresso was awful and asked for a refund.  the Italian sounding barman said it's a perfectly fine espresso and "you must pay 2.75" !no offer to make a different one or compromise in any way.  plain nasty experience.  after all we are on vacation Mario,  so please take it easy- your espresso is bitter,  watery and gross!

woLSJl4U1Un0lfYTYpCUwg.review_text: On my last day in SF, we were supposed to eat at Sotto Mare, but it was closed, so we found Mario's, which was said to be good.    Mario's really looks like a small bar or cafe; there is enough seating for maybe 20 people in the bar, and it's slightly crowded in the sense of space, but that didn't bother me too much.    When we first walked in, we weren't sure what to do because no one came to us so we seated ourselves and then requested menus at the bar.  Then we found out that there are actually servers that do that for you, and one tended to us from there.  Servers are very friendly, which was nice.  I ordered the meatball sandwich, which is HOT & delicious and possibly the most flavorful meatball sub I've eaten.  It was slices rather than a whole meatballs and covered with cheese and marinara, on foccacia bread  which was crispily toasted and served with a side of pepperoncinis.  It was an expensive sandwich ($9.75), but I would have it again.  Being the fatty I am, I had to have some of my friends' sausage sandwich, which was also really good, and a bite of my brother's canelloni, which had a homemade taste to it.    The location of Mario's makes it a good people watching spot.

kpKV8hwc-pkMDKO5eKdjlQ.review_text: I think this place has amazing character.  I love the meatball sandwich and sitting outside facing the park.  On a sunny day it is the ultimate North Beach experience. Love it.

hj7U5xIeohSoryeV2yVvRA.review_text: Apparently I had a cigar theme last night. Ducked in here while waiting for our table at the pizza place around the corner. Super chill vibe, and the bartender even juggled the oranges before slipping them into the blue moon.  Grabbed a nice table outside, and watched the parking on the street and everyone taking photos of the park at night. ?  I think that I just don't understand this part of town sometimes.

Sh_tZqIfhWHdvbAQTf5ofQ.review_text: Cigars . . . No. . . Good eats. . . yes sir Simple, yet just what the doctor ordered. We stopped at Mario's for lunch on a beautiful Sunday afternoon, post walking around North Beach all morning. The place is simple, and tight, with about 6 tables along the windows and then a counter overlooking the small kitchen, boom, that's it.  The guys were great on the service! The atmosphere is quaint and super friendly. The three of us split up a Chicken #2 panini, and the (man this was good!) eggplant panini. They were both great sandwiches. As commented by others, no sides here, just your sandwich. But, you know what, I didn't care! We three left completely satisfied. The focaccia bread was wonderful and fresh, the veggies seasoned and cooked excellently, and the chicken and the eggplant, nicely seasoned (eggplant was breaded). For a quick stop to a local shop, I definitely recommend Mario's, for a bite to eat in an old world location. And, don't be afraid to ask the boys about their coffees. They know about their coffees.

4yLpXuXv8XqeaT0GvP60SQ.review_text: This place was fantastic! My Bf and I just got back and I am beaming Im so satisfied. He ordered the chicken panini and ordered half of a grilled eggplant and vinagerette sandwich. For $5 is was huge! And the best $5 ever spent. It was cozy, busy and we barely got a table but it was close to our new house and we've always wanted to try it. Im so impressed by this place! Good coffee, no soy milk though, kind of a bummer, so I had an italian soda which was delicious.

GO0GU6sTOdgtUpAwzj1Tbg.review_text: I like this place a lot,  Compare to the rest of the places in North Beach I like their straightforward concept.  Small Cafe, small but well done menu.  Reasonable prices and great location.  Taking into consideration the location you would think this is a tourist trap and on the contrary this is more of a locals place.   The people working there are nice and seem to enjoy their jobs.  Grab some coffee, a beer and lunch and sit outside on a sunny weekend to people watch.  Go to Washington square park on a sunny weekend and walk across pick up a beer and sit outside

z-ElbRef0nw-QLwzfEZENw.review_text: When you drive by Mario's and there's a parking space right outside, you have to take it. Then you must go into Mario's, grab a seat at the bar and order a beer and a meatball sandwich. They serve it on Liguria green onion foccacia and toast it in the oven. That sandwich is one of the most delicious things that you'll ever eat: the perfect amount of sauce, cheese and meatballs nestled inside the best toasted foccacia. With pepperoncini on the side.  I've also had the eggplant sandwich and it was heaven as well, but for some reason I almost always gravitate towards the meatballs.

3uIqew23Ev1SOMVEvLHD_w.review_text: You can't beat the adorable atmosphere with rickety wooden tables and a view of the park. Get the chicken sandwich (add tomatoes if you like). Their mustard has a delicious kick to it - watch out if you're a little sensitive to horseradish-esque tastes, but it's SO GOOD! Cheap carafes of wine as well. It's not the most amazing, droolworthy, tell everyone you see meal in North Beach, but sometimes you just want to grab a leisurely sandwich in a really comfortable, cute, pleasant atmosphere. Go!!! Perfect weekend afternoon stop.

mtpek5XdI8oqrA5KCGFXZg.review_text: Mario's Bohemian is a North Beach institution.  The tables out side face Washington Square park and are perfect for people watching but I like to sit at the bar.  The service was quick and friendly. My sausage sandwich was delicious as was a cappuccino with Vov.

QH35cIYlQ9JKW27jGlrE8Q.review_text: Great sandwiches, friendly proprietors, classic North Beach charm. Ask for the Chicken #3! (Not on the menu )

xAwSWwRUpQh5GD_Cmdsr8w.review_text: The food, if you ordered a focaccio was great.  That is what they are known for.  Everything was good.   The service, on the other hand was not good.  I don't ever remember a waiter scolding me for anything.  This guy was just a bear to deal with.  We had eight people and the place was tiny.  After four failed attempts to situate ourselves and four rethinks he finally came up with a solution that should have been the first thing out of him mouth.  I asked for additional dressing for my salad and was told that there was already dressing on the salad.  I had obvioulsy tasted it and got an argument.  Then he set down a huge bowl of dressing and told me that it should be enough.  What is this guy a waiter or my mother?  Get a new waiter guys, and update you menu a little to accomodate people who can't eat wheat. I only ask for one nice salad.  You have the ingredients.

MQbaGVfwGnddzrcABnS-Fw.review_text: three letters OMG.. this place is awesome and I mean awesome.   the fococia is just sexy and the service exceptional.  the Italian sausage sandwich is heaven.  it is my new regular spot.

Zcr90BeQ8QWV32XIqpH82A.review_text: I can't believe I haven't reviewed this place!  Mario's is an institution in a neighborhood full of institutions.  The place just oozes character in its funky little way.  The sandwiches are great, the beer is cold, the location is rocking.  One of those places that so easily could have been taken over by tourists and stripped of its character (there are plenty of tourists, but the character is still intact), Mario's still is going strong.   Go with a friend or two, get a carafe of the house wine, and just enjoy.

LZzyszEXnhr3KzPs6GWM1g.review_text: Service: 2.5/5 Food: 3/5 Wait: 3/5 Price: $$ Portions: 2/5 Presentation of food: 4/5 Presentation of restaurant: 3/5 Overall: 3/5  I HAD THEIR CHICKEN PANINI WITH PESTO, ITS GREAT. BUT THE FACT THAT IM PAYING $8.50 FOR A SMALL SANDWICH... WITH NOOO SIDES WHATSOEVER, AND THEIR SALADS RANGE TO $6.50-$10! ITS QUITE PRICEY FOR SOMETHING SMALL, ITS NOT THAAAAAAT GOOD FOR IT TO BE SMALL AND EXPENSIVE. THEIR SERVICE WASN'T ALL THAT GREAT NEITHER, THEY SEEM TO DONT REALLY CARE FOR YOUR BUSINESS IF YOUR JUST THERE FOR FOOD?? IONO...

mGfCCHRkpuzfygPzg92-Ig.review_text: Great beer selection and a nice view of the park.  My panini was delicious, despite being a bit over toasted. I'd definitely come back!

UzW_6PaLFzPjP7_2Czk3Wg.review_text: I was confused by the name since I don't think they actually sell cigars.  A cigar store that sells sandwiches definitely sounds like a dive, but this place had decent Italian-style panini sandwiches.  I wasn't thrilled by my grilled eggplant sandwich flavor-wise but I'm pretty sure their other offerings are much better.  The ambiance is pretty hipster.  The staff was friendly and funny.

m6p5knAyIS79s6WNbeIdGw.review_text: This is a great and affordable spot to grab a sandwich in northbeach. It is one of the few places where you can find a meal for under $10 and they also have a pretty affordable wine list. Mario's is also located on the corner of Columbus right next to the park, which can be amazing for people watching.

kOSLWOSDJrllntYg4b-Jmw.review_text: Former "Old School" now a "hipster faux school" joke.  Quaintly triangulated corner location with old San Francisco charm.  We enjoyed the good coffee, great food, mellow local staff who were nice and efficient.  Especially loved watching the former Hispanic chef who'd whip out amazing panini's, pizzas, and salads that made you wish you had more room in your belly.  He virtually danced while he cooked, watching him cook was the enticement and entertainment.    This has been a "must stop" on regular visits to San Francisco.  On our recent "must stop", the waitress for the outside tables was efficient and friendly, but there was this mustache guy who couldn't move his face or serve a beer in the time it takes to pull a tap.  We came again the following day, service was so slow to the point where you wonder if you should help yourself.  Was left alone with our "one" beers long enough and decided to go, when I went in for the  bathroom.  I could've been a new customer since I only sat outside while partner went in for the service and the check.  I walked passed the mustachioed, a gal, and another bearded hipster guy who looked at me without saying a word nor moved their faces.  It was like the hear-see-speak no evil monkeys, lined up behind the bar.  Instead, I helped myself to the bathroom without being acknowledged.  THIS is now the place where you can use the bathroom freely without being a customer.  You don't have to worry since you won't be stopped, nor be sold a drink or food.  They won't dare to crack their faces for you. Bathroom is straight to the back, then turn right.  Would've tried the food (didn't see the Hispanic chef), but since we could only get one beer each, used our money in other parts of North Beach where they want to take it.  Lost its real San Francisco local charm, and 2 customers now.  So sad.

opVAP6IrUMSbGsbO3ez2_g.review_text: A charming little spot in North Beach to take a friend for a casual bite or to read a book and have a glass of wine alone. I work next door to Mario's so i've never had the pleasure of actually dining there but I do take-out on average once a week and i'm always envious of the people chillin in this cozy hang out. I usually order the eggplant parmesan which is made with a flavorful marinara and plenty of good cheese.  The pizza is also delicious, italian style with a cracker crust.  A filling meal or a light snack for 2.  For the quality the price can't be beat.  The wine list could use a little work but that wouldn't stop me from coming back again and again.

2U4Y0Hz6tRD1JjKUJF_Z3w.review_text: I love this tiny cafe. Not only does it have a great location by the park/good food/cozy atmosphere/nice-though-not-hovering-servers, but it plays reggae music. And I enjoy listening to Bob Marley when I eat eggplant sandwiches.

zuW3cDC5XRXS9q7Hpwwq6g.review_text: Great quick food. Authentic tasty Italian food and totally delicious focaccia sandwiches. This is a great stop for before a show at Bimbo's or before the bar run or even on a quick lunch.

ghost_id_1.review_text: I used to come here when you were still allowed to smoke cigarettes in this place. Most of the time we had tasty ciabatta at lunch or in the evening here, overlooking the square. Marios is a cosy place with character, history and patina.  I stopped by recently and was glad the place still existed. In general I felt Northbeach is stuck in time and has not moved on in the last decades. Parking the rental car was a pain.

a6mFy0UBIlmpGg8aev8YqA.review_text: Solid. My favorite is the breaded eggplant sandwich with a glass of house red. Great place to meet up wtih friends for a quick bite before hitting the town. Cappucinos are tasty, too. Hits the spot on a sunny day, if you can get a window seat. The service used to be better a few years ago. Not sure the deal there. Could just be cluelessness or a decision by the staff to treat locals like passing tourists.

hHX3dkAFo93CcG8NnUhdkg.review_text: i know this place for more than 4 years.Nice food ( sandwiches )  , kinda slow but friendly service .It's quite European style ,nice view, tasty wine...i recommended...
